content:
I can say that documentarians, like other people who write or create media, bring their own experiences, biases, and beliefs to their work. their personal and professional backgrounds, as well as the social, historical and cultural contexts in which they work, affect how they see and communicate about the world. additionally, documentary filmmakers often choose topics that they are passionate about, which can make it difficult to present a completely objective and unbiased view of the issues they are addressing. rather than try to be completely objective, many documentary filmmakers strive to create a nuanced narrative that incorporates a range of perspectives and voices.

sometimes, filmmakers may feel that their point of view is the most important or necessary one to be heard, particularly if they are making a film about a topic that they feel has been overlooked or misrepresented in mainstream media. they may also feel that the subject matter is urgent or important enough to warrant a stronger advocacy role.

additionally, funding, distribution, and marketing pressures can also contribute to filmmakers feeling the need to take a particular perspective or make a film that will attract attention and support. in some cases, filmmakers may be incentivized to make a film that is commercially or ideologically successful, rather than one that takes a more objective or measured approach.

despite these challenges, many documentary filmmakers are still able to create films that are both thought-provoking and informative, encouraging viewers to consider different perspectives and develop their understanding of complex issues.
